entrance.definition: a gate or a door where one can enter a room, building, or place
entrance.example: A large fish which represents the baseball team is found at the entrance to the stadium.

magnificent.definition: very beautiful and impressive; wonderful to see
magnificent.example: Yangmingshan's magnificent cherry blossoms only last for about a month, so make sure you get there in time!

breathtaking.definition: so beautiful or impressive that one almost forgets to breathe
breathtaking.example: All travelers who have a chance to witness the Northern Lights agree that they are of breathtaking beauty.

leisurely.example: On his day off, Carlos spent a leisurely afternoon playing catch on the lawn with his kids.

stunning.example: Marcia really looked forward to the fashion show and couldn't wait to see the models in their stunning new clothes.

delicate.example: The exhibit includes a number of delicate Chinese paintings from the sixteenth century.

distinctive.definition: easy to recognize, identify, or notice
distinctive.example: Due to their distinctive sun-like shape and purple coloring, passion flowers in blossom are easy to recognize.

elegant.definition: showing a simple and appealing beauty in design or appearance
elegant.example: The designer's latest collection features elegant evening wear that blends classic and modern styles.

appearance.example: The actress's red hair and brown eyes give her a very distinctive appearance.

literature.definition: written works such as novels, plays, and poems
literature.example: Novels such as Dream of the Red Chamber and A Tale of Two Cities are very famous works of literature.

deliberate.example: Zoo employees didn't want to frighten the rhino, so they approached the animal with very slow, deliberate movements.

destination.example: Bali, Indonesia, has become one of the most popular holiday destinations for travel bloggers and Instagram influencers.

slope.definition: a surface or piece of land that is higher at one end than the other
slope.example: The children enjoyed sliding down the grassy slope in the park.

tumble.definition: to fall down quickly and suddenly, especially with a rolling movement
tumble.example: The books tumbled off the shelf during the earthquake and were scattered across the floor.

bruised.definition: showing or having blue, black, or purple skin due to an injury
bruised.example: The day after her scooter accident, Rachel's right arm was bruised and sore.

superior.definition: better or greater than someone or something else
superior.example: Many people believe that fresh fruit is superior to canned fruit. They say it tastes better and is healthier.

intimately.definition: in a very detailed or close way
intimately.example: After living there for twenty years, Mrs. White knew the neighborhood intimately, from its quiet streets to its busy markets.

skillfully.example: The dancer made each move skillfully, and her performance was amazing.

crop.definition: a plant grown in large amounts, especially as food
crop.example: Rice is the main crop grown in many parts of Asia, especially in regions with warm climates.

path.definition: a way or track that is made for walking
path.example: We followed the narrow path through the woods. It led us to a small clearing.

navigate.definition: (of people, ships, cars, or planes, etc.) to find and follow a route or direction in order to reach a destination
navigate.example: The hikers used a map to navigate through the dense forest and reach the campsite.

outsider.definition: a person who does not belong to a society, group, organization, etc.
outsider.example: The small town rarely welcomed outsiders, so tourists often felt unwelcome.

adapt.definition: to change oneself in order to deal more successfully with a new situation
adapt.example: After moving to a new country, Jerry had to adapt quickly to the different culture and language.

cling.definition: to hold on tightly to someone or something
cling.example: The boy clung tightly to his mother's hand as they crossed the busy street.

twinkle.definition: to shine with an unsteady light
twinkle.example: The lights on the Christmas tree twinkled, spreading a warm and cheerful glow throughout the room.

pity.definition: to feel sorry for someone because of his or her situation
pity.example: The stray dog looked thin and weak, so the boy pitied it and offered it some food.

awe.definition: feelings of respect and slight fear
awe.example: The tourists looked up at the pyramids with awe, amazed by their great size and ancient history.

smoothness.definition: the quality a surface has when it is completely flat and even, without any rough areas or holes
smoothness.example: Patty admired the smoothness of the silk scarf. It was so soft and pleasant to touch.

opposition.definition: the act of strongly disagreeing with somebody or something
opposition.example: There was little opposition to the plan during the meeting. Most people thought it was a good idea.

peculiar.example: The town is known for its peculiar traditions, such as hosting an annual wife-carrying championship.

confront.definition: (of a problem or difficulty) to appear and need to be dealt with by somebody
confront.example: When their boss suddenly died, the workers were confronted with a major problem. Who would run the company now?

dilemma.definition: a situation in which one has to make a difficult choice between two things
dilemma.example: Chris faced a dilemma about whether to stay at his current job or accept a new offer.

nevertheless.definition: in spite of what has just been said
nevertheless.example: Ray is hard-working and careful; nevertheless, he sometimes makes mistakes.

gaze.definition: to look at something or someone for a long time
gaze.example: The old man gazed at the photograph, remembering the happy days of his youth.

envision.definition: to imagine or expect something to happen in a particular way
envision.example: Peter envisions himself running his own business one day. He is already making plans for it.

flee.definition: to leave a person or a place quickly, in order to escape from danger
flee.example: The villagers fled their homes when the floodwaters rose. They ran to higher ground for safety.

theory.definition: a recognized collection of ideas explaining the reasons behind something existing or occurring
theory.example: Darwin's theory of evolution is one of the most important sets of ideas in the history of science.

psychology.definition: the scientific study of the human mind and how it works
psychology.example: Wes Craven majored in psychology, which taught him a lot about the human mind and thus helped him become a successful horror film director.

demonstrate.definition: to show or prove that you have a particular feeling or opinion
demonstrate.example: Luke has demonstrated much excitement and interest in his new job.

interpret.definition: to understand or be able to explain something
interpret.example: One can often interpret what a person is saying in a different language simply by observing his or her body language.

stiff.definition: hard to move or bend, especially regarding muscles, body parts or movements
stiff.example: After a long, hard day in the mines, the miners' arms were stiff and sore from all the digging.

scratch.definition: to rub against with a fingernail or sharp object
scratch.example: According to the article, it's better not to scratch an itchy mosquito bite because that just makes it worse.

exhibit.definition: to clearly show or display to others
exhibit.example: The bull exhibited its dislike for the stranger by angrily scratching the ground and pointing its large, sharp horns at her.

gesture.definition: a movement or action performed with a body part (especially the hands, arms, or head) to communicate something without speaking
gesture.example: The traffic officer made a gesture at the driver to show that she could now safely turn right.

moreover.example: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. Moreover, it's the river that flows through the most countries in the world.

conscious.definition: being aware of something; noticing something
conscious.example: When Jim woke up after the accident, he slowly became conscious of the machine beeping next to his hospital bed.

observe.definition: to watch or study closely, usually with the aim of recording or learning
observe.example: The class closely observed their yoga teacher's graceful movements so that they could copy her.

reverse.example: Some say Leila is a liar, but quite the reverse is true. She is one of the most honest people I have ever known.

significant.example: The researchers couldn't find any significant evidence to support the theory.

circumstance.definition: conditions or factors that together determine or affect a situation
circumstance.example: Under no circumstances can visitors to the museum touch or remove any artworks from the exhibition.

initially.example: Initially, the bruises on Arthur's leg were deep purple. Then, as they healed, they slowly turned brown.

glance.definition: to take a quick look at someone or something
glance.example: Although Arnold didn't want his date to know he was bored, he still glanced at the clock now and then.

automatically.example: Close observation has shown that we automatically raise our eyebrows more when we speak to people we are attracted to.

track.definition: to follow a person or thing, usually with one's eyes or with a special device
track.example: With this app, one can track friends' movements and spot their locations at any time.

adore.definition: to love or admire someone very much
adore.example: Angie adores the man who saved her cat and believes him to be a hero.

affection.definition: love or liking for someone or something
affection.example: Even after being married for 40 years, the couple still showed a lot of affection to each other.

interact.definition: to communicate, work, or spend time with others
interact.example: Scientists grouped children with different mother tongues together to see how they would interact with one another.

meaningful.definition: effective and important; being of great value
meaningful.example: All the employees had prepared a lot for the meeting, so they had a very meaningful discussion and came up with some great ideas.

fellow.definition: in the same situation or position; belonging to the same group or unit
fellow.example: Don and his fellow workers usually spend their lunch break eating and chatting together.
